user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 14.2.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The for loop uses two loop counters (i and j). The first clause initializes only i (j was set before the loop), the second clause uses both i and j, and the third clause increments both ++i and ++j. Moreover i is modified inside the loop body (i++ when a backslash is found). This violates Rule 14.2’s requirement of only one loop counter, that the loop counter not be modified in the loop body, and the initialization/usage constraints.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/1514.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n as much as possible.
You CAN just insert probe functions to the original code.
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                                     size_t quoted_len,
                                     const char *unquoted,
                                     size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (! charsequalcaseless (quoted[i], unquoted[j]))
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please provide the modified MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n code.
